div.div: 2. Subnet Boardcasting: - means boardcasting to local network only. eg: - if my subnet is 10.144.116.0/24 then subnet boardcast address is 10.144.116.255

div.div:
Other common multicast groups you see
=================standard==============
ff02::1
All nodes
ff02::2
All routers===============Service Discovery Groups============
🔹 ff02::c
SSDP / UPnP (service discovery)
🔹 ff02::fb
mDNS (.local names, printers, etc.)
🔹 ff02::1:3
DHCPv6 servers & relay agents
ff05::2
Site-local routers================Service Discovery Groups========
ff02::1:ffxx:xxxx

switch.text: Other common multicast groups you see...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1210px; margin-left: 390px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Every IPv6 address automatically calcuates and then joins its corresponding solicited-node multicast group
Automatic Calculation
When a device configures an IPv6 address on an interface, it automatically calculates the solicited-node multicast address using this formula
Solicited-Node Multicast = ff02::1:ff + (last 24 bits of IPv6 address):
Multiple Addresses = Multiple Groups
If a device has multiple IPv6 addresses, it joins multiple solicited-node multicast groups:
Interface eth0:
├─ 2409:40d0:2414:e090::200 → joins ff02::1:ff00:0200
├─ 2409:40d0:2414:e090::500 → joins ff02::1:ff00:0500
└─ fe80::1234:5678:abcd:ef01 → joins ff02::1:ffcd:ef01
It's Done by the OS/Network Stack

switch.text: Every IPv6 address automatically calcuates and then joins its corresponding solicited-node multicast group...

path.style: stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));
fill: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255)); stroke: light-dark(rgb(0, 0, 0), rgb(255, 255, 255));

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1820px; margin-left: 410px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; color: #000000;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: "Helvetica"; color: light-dark(#000000, #ffffff); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Multicast Filter List the NIC has a hardware filter that decides which packets to pass to the operating system, and
The NIC (Network Interface Card) has dedicated hardware circuits that perform filtering WITHOUT involving the CPU
IPv6 multicast addresses are mapped to Ethernet multicast MAC addresses using this formula:
IPv6 Multicast: ff02::1:ff46:6b42
└─────────┘
(last 32 bits)
Ethernet MAC: 33:33 + last 32 bits of IPv6 address
= 33:33:ff:46:6b:42
the NIC adds 33:33:ff:46:6b:42 to its multicast filter list:
NIC Multicast MAC Filter List:
├─ Your unicast MAC (e.g., AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF) ← Always there
├─ 33:33:00:00:00:01 ← ff01::1 and ff02::1
├─ 33:33:00:00:00:0c ← ff02::c
├─ 33:33:00:00:00:fb ← ff02::fb
├─ 33:33:00:01:00:03 ← ff02::1:3
├─ 33:33:ff:00:12:34 ← ff02::1:ff00:1234
├─ 33:33:ff:46:6b:42 ← ff02::1:ff46:6b42
├─ 33:33:ff:9f:66:8d ← ff02::1:ff9f:668d
└─ 33:33:ff:bd:03:cf ← ff02::1:ffbd:3cf

switch.text: Multicast Filter List the NIC has a hardware filter that decides which packets to pass to the operating system...
